Argumentative Writing on Contemporary MÄori Issues

Learning Objectives

  • Analyse and construct persuasive arguments on contemporary MÄori issues.
  • Apply whakapapa (connections) and mana (respect) when discussing MÄori perspectives.
  • Develop critical thinking by evaluating different viewpoints.
  • Write a structured argumentative essay using evidence from credible sources.

Cultural Context & Safety Notes

He WhakataukÄ« (MÄori Proverb): "Kia whakatÅmuri te haere whakamua" â€“ "I walk backwards into the future with my eyes fixed on the past."

Cultural Considerations:

  • Ensure discussions remain respectful of MÄori perspectives.
  • Encourage students to consider Te Tiriti o Waitangi (Treaty of Waitangi) principles.
  • Use appropriate tikanga (protocols) when discussing sensitive topics.
  • Provide trigger warnings if discussing historical injustices.

Lesson Activities

1. Exploring Contemporary MÄori Issues

Task: In small groups, research one of the following topics:

  • MÄori representation in media
  • Land rights and whenua (land) disputes
  • The impact of colonisation on MÄori health
  • Te reo MÄori revitalisation in schools

Discussion: Share findings and debate different perspectives.

2. Crafting an Argument

Task: Choose a stance on your issue and draft an argument using:

  • A clear thesis statement
  • Evidence from credible sources (e.g., news articles, academic papers)
  • Counterarguments and rebuttals

3. Peer Review & Reflection

Task: Exchange essays with a partner and provide constructive feedback.

Reflection: How did your perspective evolve during this process?

Assessment Rubric

Criteria Excellent (5) Proficient (3-4) Developing (1-2)
Argument Structure Clear thesis, strong evidence, logical flow Some structure, adequate evidence Weak argument, lacks coherence
Cultural Sensitivity Respectful, integrates MÄori perspectives Some awareness, minor missteps Lacks cultural consideration
Critical Thinking Deep analysis, strong rebuttals Basic analysis, some counterarguments Limited analysis, weak rebuttals

Extension Activities

  • Debate: Hold a formal debate on one of the issues.
  • Multimedia Presentation: Create a video or podcast advocating for a MÄori issue.
  • Guest Speaker: Invite a MÄori advocate or academic to discuss their perspective.

Adaptations for Diverse Learners

  • Struggling Writers: Provide sentence starters or graphic organisers.
  • ESOL Students: Offer vocabulary lists and simplified texts.
  • Advanced Learners: Challenge them to include whakataukÄ« (proverbs) in their arguments.

``` --- ## **Teacher Implementation Guide** ### **Lesson Breakdown** **Lesson 1:** - Introduce contemporary MÄori issues (videos, articles, discussion). - Group research on selected topics. **Lesson 2:** - Teach argument structure (thesis, evidence, counterarguments). - Begin drafting essays. **Lesson 3:** - Peer review and feedback. - Final revisions and submission. --- ## **Assessment Suggestions** - **Formative:** Peer feedback, draft check-ins. - **Summative:** Final essay graded using rubric. --- ## **Extension Activities** - **Community Engagement:** Interview local MÄori leaders. - **Creative Response:** Write a persuasive speech or op-ed. --- ## **Adaptations** - **Visual Learners:** Use infographics or mind maps. - **Kinesthetic Learners:** Role-play debates. This resource is **ready for immediate classroom use**, aligns with **NZC English standards**, and ensures **cultural authenticity and accessibility**. Let me know if you'd like any modifications!
